table.insight: Anomalies from Physical Verification of Inventory
table.description: Shortages result in write-offs (expense), while excess quantities may be recorded as gains, directly impacting profit or loss for the period.

When non-routine inventory movements are recorded (e.g., scrapping obsolete stock or revaluation adjustments), they result in gains or losses that impact profitability through expense or income recognition.
When idle or obsolete inventory is identified, the write-down or provision expense hits the P&L, reducing net profit through increased expenses or losses.
Sampling anomalies increase production or quality control costs. If defective items are found, related expenses (e.g., material loss, testing waste) hit the P&L as COGS or quality-related expenses.
Changes leading to write-offs or adjustments for expired goods impact P&L via increased expense recognition for obsolete or unusable inventory.
